Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I strengthened my skills in speaking/writing/reading in Vietnamese.
I learned Vietnamese language and culture.
More conversational Vietnamese, more vocabulary. A continuation of L1 Vietnamese.
I got a much better grasp on Vietnamese

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very interactive/memorable and Thy Quang helps develop a close knit community within the class itself.

This course heavily focuses on quizzes, projects, and collaborative work. There is not a large emphasis on exams. I prefer the emphasis on projects over exams. Unfortunately, this class can be very disorganized since we do not use Canvas at all. Deadlines are often confusing and grades are generally a mystery. You don't really know your grade until the end of the semester.
All of the strengths and weaknesses L1 Vietnamese had, L2 Vietnamese has.

Improvements:
A greater adherence to the agenda released at the beginning of the weak.
Strengths:
Immersive learning with many supplementary activities and engaging projects with my peers.

The class is set up in a very relaxed way that reduces stress, but still facilitates learning. Thay Quang effectively brings in his own cultural anecdotes to supplement the textbook, enriching the course greatly.

Some units were covered more in-depth than others. Sometimes assignments were not returned with corrections or comments, which made it frustrating. I think that Thay Quang could improve this by setting a clear schedule for the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student interested in learning Vietnamese who wants to join a Vietnamese community. You will undoubtedly grow very close with your classmates by the end of the course.
If you want to learn Vietnamese, heritage or not
Yes, of course. Vietnamese is a fun class, and Thay Quang is a fun, lenient, and understanding professor.

YES! As a student who did not speak any Vietnamese going into L1, I highly recommend this second-semester continuation of the course. Thay Quang is an effective, knowledgeable, and kind instructor who goes out of his way to cater to the needs of each student.
